messageBody:
The really best solution to avoid all this mess (autoexec.bat...) is to use Ant. If you are not working with Ant, invest a few hours to set it running.

Ok, to run Ant, you have to set the ANT_HOME environment variable...

You can then easily and precisely define what your classpath is and forget about these $%&#^ global variables :-)

What I do:

- in my build.xml file, I do not make any assumptions about where my project will be compiled. No explicit reference to the classpath is made
- the classpath is defined with the <classpath></classpath> task
- the script needs some variable (like the location of the javahelp libs) so I have a mk.bat script that call ant and passes all the needed variables with the -D option
- instead of 'ant build' I type 'mk build'

to build the project on another environment, only the mk.bat file must be changed

-Vladimir

build.xml

<property name="build_dir" value="build" />
<property name="src_dir" value="src" />

<target name="build" depends="init">
<javac srcdir="${src_dir}"
destdir="${build_dir}"
debug="on"
verbose="off"
deprecation="on">
<classpath>
<pathelement location="${javahelp_home}/lib/jh.jar" />
</classpath>
</javac>
<copy todir="${build_dir}" >
<fileset dir="${src_dir}"
excludes="**/*.java,**/*.*~" />
</copy>
</target>

mk.bat:

c:\...\ant.exe -Djavahelp_home=${JHHOME}/javahelp $1
